title: 103_s1952
content:
The United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995 provides specifications for the commemorative coin. The Secretary of the Treasury shall issue not more than 500,000 $1 silver coins, weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The design of the coins shall feature a rose, the national floral emblem, and a frontal view of the French facade of the United States Botanic Garden, with inscriptions of the coin's value and the year 1995. The coins issued under this Act shall be legal tender as provided in section 5103 of title 31, United States Code. The design of the coins shall include inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary shall obtain silver for the coins minted under this Act only from stockpiles established under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design for the coins authorized by this Act shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden and the Commission of Fine Arts. The design shall also be reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 - ISSUANCE OF COINS.

(a) Quality of Coins: Coins minted under this Act may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities.

(b) Mint Facility: Only one facility of the United States Mint may be used to strike any quality of the coins minted under this Act.

(c) Period of Issuance: The Secretary may issue coins minted under this Act from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995.

SEC. 6 - SALE OF COINS. The coins authorized under this Act shall be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value of the coins, plus surcharge. Bulk sales will be available at a reasonable discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a discount before the issuance of such coins. Sales under this subsection shall include a surcharge of $10 per coin. - General waiver of procurement regulations.
- No law governing procurement or public contracts applies to goods or services necessary for this Act.
- Nothing in this section relieves a person entering into a contract under this Act from complying with equal employment opportunity laws.
- Distribution of surcharges: All surcharges received from coin sales under this Act shall be promptly paid by the Secretary to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden.
- Audits. The Comptroller General has the right to examine the books, records, documents, and other data of the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden related to expenditures. This Act is titled the "United States Botanic Garden Commemorative Coin Act of 1995" and specifies coin specifications. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 500,000 $1 silver coins with specific specifications. The design includes a rose and the United States Botanic Garden facade. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The Secretary will obtain silver for minting coins from stockpiles. The design will be selected in consultation with relevant bodies. Coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities from a single mint facility. The issuance period is from January 1, 1995, to December 31, 1995. The Secretary will sell coins at a price including face value, surcharge, and design costs. Bulk sales will have discounts, prepaid orders accepted with discounts, and a $10 surcharge per coin. Additionally, there is a general waiver of procurement regulations. SEC. 7 of the Act provides a general waiver of procurement regulations for goods and services needed for the Act. However, this waiver does not exempt compliance with equal employment opportunity laws. SEC. 8 states that surcharges from coin sales will go to the National Fund for the United States Botanic Garden. SEC. 9 allows the Comptroller General to audit the Fund's expenditures related to these surcharges.
